Award.AwardTitle: Competing Pathways in Reactions of Oxygen-Containing Free Radicals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms - A Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. H. Floyd Davis and students at Cornell University will study photoinduced and bimolecular reactions involving atmospherically important oxygen-containing free radicals. Using the crossed laser- molecular beam method, the branching ratios for competing bromine dioxide and iodine dioxide photodissociation pathways will be determined. Elementary radical-radical reactions involving diatomic halogen oxide free radicals (e.g., ClO + BrO) will be studied in crossed molecular beams. A method involving photodepletion of highly-reactive neutral halogen oxide molecules with near-threshold photoionization detection will be developed to determine wavelength-dependent absorption cross sections for species that cannot be prepared in pure form. The proposed studies will provide experimental benchmarks, including ionization energies, bond dissociation energies, and branching ratios for key atmospheric reactions induced by absorption of solar radiation or bimolecular collisions. These quantities should help facilitate direct tests of quantum theoretical models for reactions, and should be of use in atmospheric models for ozone-depleting processes.

Halogen atoms (chlorine, bromine, and iodine) undergo reactions in the Earth's atmosphere that destroy ozone, an important molecule that provides protection from harmful ultraviolet solar radiation. The ozone-destroying reactions involve molecules with unpaired electrons known as free radicals. Because of their extremely reactive nature, most free radicals cannot be prepared in pure form, making their study difficult. In this research project, laboratory techniques involving laser beams (collimated beams of light) and molecular beams (collimated beams of molecules), are used to study chemical reactions involving atmospheric free radicals. In addition, the Davis group will establish a high-school lending program for newly-developed low-cost ($25) absorption spectrometers. This will help bring hands-on laboratory experiments, usually requiring high-cost equipment, to the high school classroom. Exposing high school students to the design, construction, and use of scientific instruments can be used to teach critical thinking skills and help students understand and appreciate science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemistry of our atmosphere involves reactions of molecules, called free radicals, produced by processes induced by sunlight. The presence of unpaired electrons in free radicals causes them to be highly reactive, and also highly colored. As a consequence free radicals absorb visible light from the sun, causing them to break up into smaller free radicals that can react with other molecules. Some chain reactions involving free radicals can be harmful to our environment. For example, the destruction of the ozone layer that protects us from the sun’s harmful ultraviolet light resulted primarily from reactions involving free radicals containing oxygen and chlorine produced by man-made compounds released to the atmosphere.

  The balance of ozone in our atmosphere is also affected by reactions involving free radicals produced naturally. For example, iodine released by algae in coastal regions participates in chemical reactions that form free radicals such as iodine monoxide (IO) and iodine dioxide (OIO). Unlike many chlorine-containing free radicals, which have been known for more than 100 years, iodine dioxide (OIO) and the closely related molecule bromine dioxide (OBrO), were only first characterized spectroscopically in the 1990’s. Because of their extreme reactivity, these radicals are very difficult to study, so many unanswered questions remained about their role in our atmosphere.

This project focused on laboratory studies of reactions involving oxygen-containing free radicals, including IO, BrO, OIO, and OBrO. Knowledge gained through laboratory studies of radicals under carefully-controlled conditions makes it possible to predict and model chemistry occurring in complicated environments such as our atmosphere. For example, we produced a molecular beam containing OIO radicals in an instrument that we built, and studied how they break apart upon absorption of visible light. Depending on the color of the light used we observed two different processes. Absorption of blue light caused the OIO to break apart into IO + O, whereas absorption of green, yellow, orange or red light produced I + O2. Although production of IO + O  does not affect ozone concentrations in the atmosphere, the I + O2 channel is important to understand because it depletes the ozone in our atmosphere via subsequent free-radical chain reactions. Our studies also allowed us to determine fundamental thermodynamic quantities such as bond strengths very accurately, making it possible to predict how free radicals behave at different temperatures.  

This research was conducted in a university laboratory primarily by graduate and undergraduate students. A large fraction of the funds were used to support students both in stipends and tuition, thereby contributing to the education of our youth. In addition, funds from this grant were used to develop and make available simple low-cost ($25) scientific instruments that can be used by high school students in chemistry and physics classes. Most commercially-available instruments have been too expensive for secondary schools, so we anticipate that this will open new educational opportunities.
